BOSTON, MA (CPS)—Some
colleges actually may be
weighting their course offerings
towards math and science to
lure larger corporate contributions, according to a new study
by a Boston investment firm,
"For many universities and
colleges, selling their programs
to corporations and other
philanthropic agencies and individuals is key to economic
viability," says the Franklin
Research and Development
Corporation study.
"But the desire to create
greater corporate (contributions) can change a school's
policies and practices," the
report warns. Many schools are
becoming increasingly dependent on financial support from
the private sector because the
public sector—the federal and
state governments—are giving
less aid to colleges,
Corporate contributions to
education—the
highest
category of corporate giving—
reached an estimated $1.29
billion last year, up 3.2 percent

from the previous year. But
while contributions increase,
the report points out, "the
diversification of support may
narrow" as corporations "seek
greater control over universities
in order to access the best
minds and technology for their
own corporate goals."
And with the high demand
for scientists, engineers and
computer experts, more corporate support goes into high
tech areas and less into liberal
arts programs.
Already, the report says,
there is evidence that arts and
humanities courses are suffering as colleges rush to create
new math, science, and
engineering courses to attract
corporate givers.
But others disagree with the
study's warnings. "It is true
that business and industry tend
to make grants in areas that are

Alan Cranston to Speak at
Kennedy Memorial Lecture
_
California Senator Alan
Cranston, who ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic
Presidential nomination in
1984, will speak in Shriver Hall
next Tuesday. Cranston, who
will speak on "Arms Control",
will deliver the 1985 John F.
Kennedy and Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Lecture on International Relations. The
speech will begin at 8:30 p.m.
Cranston, one of the country's chief proponents of
nuclear arms control, is the
ranking Democrat on the Arms
Control Subcommittee. He also
serves on the Banking, Housing
and Urban Affairs, Foreign
Relations, Democratic Policy,
Affairs
Veterans'
and
Committees.
The first Democratic senator
from California to win election
to a third term, Cranston was
elected Senate Democratic

Whip in January, 1977. In
1982, he was elected to his
fourth successive term as Whip,
the first Democrat in fifty years
to achieve that distinction.
Last year, his presidential
candidacy received notoriety
because of his strong support
for a nuclear freeze. Cranston
met with little success, however,
and dropped out of the race
early.
The Kennedy Lectureship is
sponsored annually by the Student Council. In the past, the
Committee on Committees has
appointed a chairman of the
lectureship. This year, however,
no chairman was named, and
Council President Jon Lana
has organized the event himself.
"Time constraints put us in
a situation where finding a
chairman and finding a speaker
would have been difficult,"
Lana said. "And once you go

through the excitement of getting a speaker, it seems kind of
unfair to give the drudgery of
setting it up to someone else."
When asked why he selected
Cranston to deliver the lecture,
Lana noted that the program is
designed to bring "major
figures on international affairs
to Hopkins," and that he
believes Cranston is such a
person.

How to Cheat in Science and Get Away With It
by John Waters
"How to Cheat in Science
and Not Get Caught" was the
title of the lecture given Tuesday night by Nicholas Wade as
the fourth part of the Public Interest in Science lecture series.
Wade,a member of the New
York Times editorial board and
co-author of Betrayers of the
Truth: Fraud and Deceit in the
Halls of Science, spoke on the
ways in which deceit and error
can be incorporated into accepted scientific theory and
practice.
Although Wade's address
was to be the last in the series,
the third lecture, "Decapitating
America: Why Can't Anyone
Teach Science?" by Robert
Pollack, has been rescheduled
for May 1.
Wade began his lecture by
commenting on the apparent
absurdity of falsifying scientific
information. Because science is
viewed as a self-correcting
system, anyone who would
knowingly cheat would be a
madman, because he is bound
to get caught sooner or later.
Incidences of cheating in
science are viewed by the scientific community as "a problem
of individual psychopathology,
and as such, do not really
reflect on science itself" The
truth of the matter, Wade
argued, is a far different story.
"Science doesn't work in
anything like the way scientists
are taught to think it works,"
he said.
To understand how science
can be deceived, Wade claimed
that one must first understand
how scientific research results
become science. The circulati9n
to the scientific community of

significant research results is
achieved primarily in scientific
journals; consequently, it is in
the publication process that the
checking mechanisms of science
exist.
Whenever an article is submitted to a journal, it is circulated among a panel of
referees who judge the experimental methods and results
to determine whether or not the
article should be published. A
second checking mechanism of
science is the process of peer
review which occurs during
research grant applications to
insure the just distribution of
funds.
The last, and theoretically
strictest, test of a research
report is replication of the
study. Reproducability of study
results lies at the foundation of
the scientific method, through
which it is assumed science is
practiced.
In practice, however, the
checking mechanisms of science
do not always work. In all the
cases of scientific fraud which
Wade and Broad uncover in
their book, none were uncovered by science's alleged
process of self-correction. The
built-in quality control which
science is supposed to have is
one of the basic reasons why
scientists are treated as experts
by the general public: we feel
they cannot lie, for their
discipline itself won't allow
them to lie.
Most of the cases of fraud in
science which Wade studied
arose because science is both a
discipline and a career. Under
pressure for research positions,
refunding, professional advancement, and prestige, it
often becomes necessary for a

scientist to produce results
which he does not really have,
or to report experiments which
he has neither finished nor even
started. Although one would
like to trust the processes of
review mentioned above,
history shows them as fallible.
For example, in the case of
microbiologist John Long,
"there was a failure of all three
mechanisms to detect gross
fraud." Long worked at the
prestigious Massachusetts
General Hospital as a cancer
researcher
investigating
Hodgkins disease. He succeeded where all other researchers
had failed; he established
several cell lines of Hodgkins
disease in the test tube, where
they usually die after a short
period. The cells led Long to a
long and respected research
career, during which his results
were frequently published, including the Proceedings of the
National Academy ofSciences.
He was also awarded $759,000
from the National Institutes of
Health to continue this
research.
Long became so productive
that it led to his downfall. A
junior researcher was astonished at how fast Long completed
an experiment. After researching the matter, he proved
that the experiment could not
have taken place. "It was later
discovered," said Wade,"that
Long's cells were not even those
of a human. They were found
to belong to a northern Colombian brown-footed owl
monkey." The chromosonial
patterns of the cells, clearly not
those of a human being, occupied a half page in the Proceedings of the National
Academy of Sciences. "The

monkey cells," said Wade,
"made monkeys out of just
about everyone."
In Long's case, the failure to
detect such wrong-doing arose
from the respect for his position
as a distinguished researcher.
Furthermore, because science
and recognition in science are
based on originality, no one
would try to replicate results
which already appeared
established. Researchers' use of
raw data is also assumed to be
sacrosanct. "Merely asking to
look at raw data is tantamount
to an accusation."
To illustrate this, Wade
related the experiment of
psychologist Robert Rawlins.
Rawlins wrote to professors
who had their experimental
results published. In what is
primarily the only way of verifying the truth of an experiment, researchers appeared to
be quite inept. "More than half
of the professors reported their
data lost or destroyed. Of the
seven returned, three contained
gross errors."
Because there are no clearcut rules for the attribution of
credit in journal articles, many
professors can claim work that
is not really their own. The entire lab-chief-graduate student
relationship is capable of being
exploited.
The most shocking example
of this actually came to decide
the 1974 Nobel Prize for
Physics. Jocelyn Bell, a
graduate student in astronomy
at Cambridge, was operating a
radio-dish antenna which she
had built in her spare time.
While working on something
not related to her project for
her advisor, she detected an extremely regular pulse of radio

waves. After notifying the
directors of the lab, "the
British Parliament was informed that Cambridge was in contact with an extraterrestrial
civilization."
After Bell detected a similar
radio source, the theory was
thrown out. What Bell actually discovered were pulsars. In
1974, the discovery was rewarded with the Nobel Prize.
However, because the published results appeared with Anthony Hewish, her lab-chief, as
first author, the prize committee decided to award him the
prize.
Another enormously important factor in getting scientific
work published is the rhetorical
effectiveness of the research
report. Because results which
are either too far from or too
close to ideal results are difficult to publish, it becomes
tempting to "doctor" research
results.
Wade ended his presentation
with an explanation of how to
cheat in science and not get
caught:
(1)Publish many plausible findings, but none so original as to
stir controversy;(2)list as many
colleagues as possible as coauthors;(3) destroy all of your
original research data as soon
as you invent them; (4) praise
peer review members and journal reviewers and cite their
work prominently in all you put
before them;(5) use your grant
money to get bright young grad
students and then co-author all
of their work; (6) cultivate
friendships with anyone with a
Swedish name. "If you follow
all of these steps, who knows,
you just might win the Nobel
Prize."

dregs. You know those clowns

mostly all high and afraid of

commenting on the apparent
absurdity of falsifying scientific
information. Because science is
viewed as a self-correcting
system, anyone who would
knowingly cheat would be a
madman, because he is bound
to get caught sooner or later.
Incidences of cheating in
science are viewed by the scientific community as "a problem
of individual psychopathology,
and as such, do not really
reflect on science itself" The
truth of the matter, Wade
argued, is a far different story.
"Science doesn't work in
anything like the way scientists
are taught to think it works,"
he said.
To understand how science
can be deceived, Wade claimed
that one must first understand
how scientific research results
become science. The circulati9n
to the scientific community of

significant research results is
achieved primarily in scientific
journals; consequently, it is in
the publication process that the
checking mechanisms of science
exist.
Whenever an article is submitted to a journal, it is circulated among a panel of
referees who judge the experimental methods and results
to determine whether or not the
article should be published. A
second checking mechanism of
science is the process of peer
review which occurs during
research grant applications to
insure the just distribution of
funds.
The last, and theoretically
strictest, test of a research
report is replication of the
study. Reproducability of study
results lies at the foundation of
the scientific method, through
which it is assumed science is
practiced.
In practice, however, the
checking mechanisms of science
do not always work. In all the
cases of scientific fraud which
Wade and Broad uncover in
their book, none were uncovered by science's alleged
process of self-correction. The
built-in quality control which
science is supposed to have is
one of the basic reasons why
scientists are treated as experts
by the general public: we feel
they cannot lie, for their
discipline itself won't allow
them to lie.
Most of the cases of fraud in
science which Wade studied
arose because science is both a
discipline and a career. Under
pressure for research positions,
refunding, professional advancement, and prestige, it
often becomes necessary for a

scientist to produce results
which he does not really have,
or to report experiments which
he has neither finished nor even
started. Although one would
like to trust the processes of
review mentioned above,
history shows them as fallible.
For example, in the case of
microbiologist John Long,
"there was a failure of all three
mechanisms to detect gross
fraud." Long worked at the
prestigious Massachusetts
General Hospital as a cancer
researcher
investigating
Hodgkins disease. He succeeded where all other researchers
had failed; he established
several cell lines of Hodgkins
disease in the test tube, where
they usually die after a short
period. The cells led Long to a
long and respected research
career, during which his results
were frequently published, including the Proceedings of the
National Academy ofSciences.
He was also awarded $759,000
from the National Institutes of
Health to continue this
research.
Long became so productive
that it led to his downfall. A
junior researcher was astonished at how fast Long completed
an experiment. After researching the matter, he proved
that the experiment could not
have taken place. "It was later
discovered," said Wade,"that
Long's cells were not even those
of a human. They were found
to belong to a northern Colombian brown-footed owl
monkey." The chromosonial
patterns of the cells, clearly not
those of a human being, occupied a half page in the Proceedings of the National
Academy of Sciences. "The

monkey cells," said Wade,
"made monkeys out of just
about everyone."
In Long's case, the failure to
detect such wrong-doing arose
from the respect for his position
as a distinguished researcher.
Furthermore, because science
and recognition in science are
based on originality, no one
would try to replicate results
which already appeared
established. Researchers' use of
raw data is also assumed to be
sacrosanct. "Merely asking to
look at raw data is tantamount
to an accusation."
To illustrate this, Wade
related the experiment of
psychologist Robert Rawlins.
Rawlins wrote to professors
who had their experimental
results published. In what is
primarily the only way of verifying the truth of an experiment, researchers appeared to
be quite inept. "More than half
of the professors reported their
data lost or destroyed. Of the
seven returned, three contained
gross errors."
Because there are no clearcut rules for the attribution of
credit in journal articles, many
professors can claim work that
is not really their own. The entire lab-chief-graduate student
relationship is capable of being
exploited.
The most shocking example
of this actually came to decide
the 1974 Nobel Prize for
Physics. Jocelyn Bell, a
graduate student in astronomy
at Cambridge, was operating a
radio-dish antenna which she
had built in her spare time.
While working on something
not related to her project for
her advisor, she detected an extremely regular pulse of radio

waves. After notifying the
directors of the lab, "the
British Parliament was informed that Cambridge was in contact with an extraterrestrial
civilization."
After Bell detected a similar
radio source, the theory was
thrown out. What Bell actually discovered were pulsars. In
1974, the discovery was rewarded with the Nobel Prize.
However, because the published results appeared with Anthony Hewish, her lab-chief, as
first author, the prize committee decided to award him the
prize.
Another enormously important factor in getting scientific
work published is the rhetorical
effectiveness of the research
report. Because results which
are either too far from or too
close to ideal results are difficult to publish, it becomes
tempting to "doctor" research
results.
Wade ended his presentation
with an explanation of how to
cheat in science and not get
caught:
(1)Publish many plausible findings, but none so original as to
stir controversy;(2)list as many
colleagues as possible as coauthors;(3) destroy all of your
original research data as soon
as you invent them; (4) praise
peer review members and journal reviewers and cite their
work prominently in all you put
before them;(5) use your grant
money to get bright young grad
students and then co-author all
of their work; (6) cultivate
friendships with anyone with a
Swedish name. "If you follow
all of these steps, who knows,
you just might win the Nobel
Prize."
